body:
Accounts that have permission to access datastores are targeted by attackers. Requiring multi-factor authentication (MFA) on those accounts is an easy way to reduce the risk of data breaches or data tampering.

Multi-factor authentication (MFA) is an important tool in protecting corporate resources. MFA, also called 2-step verification (2SV), requires users to verify their identity through something they know (such as a password) plus something they have (such as a physical key or access code).
name: Ensure Datastores are not accessible by users without MFA
remediationDescription:
First of all, identify which users have access to Datastores. You can do this easily by checking the Failed Assets of this Security Control.

Make sure these users have MFA activated. Depending on the provider and the service you use, check out the following resources:

#### AWS

[Enabling MFA devices for users in AWS](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_mfa_enable.html)

#### Azure

[Common Conditional Access policy: Require MFA for administrators](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/conditional-access/howto-conditional-access-policy-admin-mfa#create-a-conditional-access-policy)

#### Alibaba

[Enable an MFA device for an Alibaba Cloud account](https://www.alibabacloud.com/help/en/resource-access-management/latest/enable-an-mfa-device-for-an-alibaba-cloud-account)

#### Azure

[Secure user sign-in events with Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/authentication/tutorial-enable-azure-mfa)
description: Datastores that are accessible by users without MFA
